awd_titl_txt: Quantum Magnetometers for Rapid Identification of Resonance Frequencies in Explosives, Pharmaceuticals, and Other Substances
awd_abstract_narration:
Crystalline solids, such as explosives and pharmaceuticals, have intrinsic resonances that provide a unique radio-frequency fingerprint for the material. Simply exciting the sample with a magnetic wave at its resonance frequency, yields a signal.  However, weak signal strength and months-long searches for resonances in unstudied materials prevent ready adoption of this inexpensive and simple technique, known as nuclear quadrupole resonance.  Quantum magnetometers, with sensitivities better than standard coil detectors, help with the former problem, but will, with this project, be developed to increase the search speed, potentially five orders of magnitude faster than the conventional method.  Despite the difficulty of discovering new resonance lines, researchers have pursued the use of quadrupole resonance for substance detection in a few applications of critical importance for security and society; in particular, the detection of explosives and the identification of counterfeit from real medicine at checkpoints. The adoption of quadrupole resonance for checkpoint and standards applications would greatly expand if resonance lines could be quickly identified for new materials.  In addition to national security benefits, the project will improve science, technology, engineering and mathematics education within George Mason by forging strong ties between the Electrical Engineering and Physics Departments through revitalized laboratory courses. Furthermore, by creating undergraduate internship projects focused on K-12 educational experiences, fledgling science teachers will be nurtured and seeds of a diverse and competitive technology and engineering workforce will be planted.

Atomic magnetometers are fundamentally different sensors than coils.  The use of optically aligned atoms as the detection medium and optical read-out of the sensor with a laser gives a better detection sensitivity than coils; noise in the magnetometer is fundamentally limited by quantum fluctuations.   Moreover, the operating frequency of the magnetometer can easily be changed to match the frequency of the excitation with a small static magnetic field.  In light of these advantages, the excitation frequency can be swept continuously, as opposed to pulsed excitation at a single operating frequency, obviating the need for a point by point search.  With pulsed excitation the material must return to an equilibrium condition before another signal is acquired; often long wait times are required between data acquisitions.  However by sweeping up through higher frequencies, then back down to the original frequency, the material is automatically returned to equilibrium.  In this way, the long wait times that compromise the effectiveness of standard pulse techniques is avoided.  As part of the project, the following goals will be met: 
1)	Magnetometer cells with an active volume of 2 cm3 will be designed and constructed.  The resulting magnetometer will have sub-femtoTesla sensitivity. The small volume is critical for the practical implementation of the resonance search with a limited quantity of material.

2)	Continuously tuning the magnetometer to a changing frequency will not alter its sensitivity.

3)	The sensitivity of the magnetometer can be retained while resonant excitation on the order of a 100 micro Tesla is applied to a sample a couple centimeters away. Coil geometry and common mode rejection schemes using a second magnetometer will be employed.

4)	If the above three goals are achieved, the search speed for resonance frequencies can be improved by as much as five orders of magnitude over conventional techniques.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this project was the use of optically-pumped atoms to measure magnetic fields oscillating at radio-frequency RF fields for potential use in defense and medical applications, as well as materials characterization.  Prior to the project, these quantum sensors were shown to have exquisite sensitivity in laboratory settings.  In this work, we pushed the sensors towards in the field applications, by increasing detection speed, robustly rejecting interference, and decreasing the required number of atoms for sensitive detection.   

Search speed for substances of interest was increased on both theoretical and experimental fronts.  On the theoretical side, a collaboration was formed with Dr. Chaudry of NIST, to extend the publicly available database NIST-JARVIS to include the calculation of electric field gradient at nuclear sites in over 15,000 materials. The electric field gradient determines the intrinsic nuclear frequency of a material.  These resonance frequencies can be used both for detection checkpoints as well as materials characterization.  

On the experimental side, the ease of resonantly tuning a quantum magnetometer was taken advantage of to simultaneously measure two distinct frequencies, as well as to inter-leave measurements with little dead-time between measurements.  The latter demonstration was done with ammonium nitrate and potassium chlorate, both explosives used in improvised explosive devices.   As a pre-cursor to these experiments, the potassium-39 resonance frequency in potassium chlorate was measured directly for the first time.  Furthermore, pulse sequences were designed and demonstrated to maximize signal detection per unit time for spin-3/2 nuclei.

Interference, whether self-generated or from external sources, was reduced in order to be able to see small signals from materials of interest.   Self-generated interference was reduced by the design of coils used to excite the material inside, but have a residual field more than five orders of magnitude smaller at the position of the magnetometer.   Furthermore, atomic gradiometers with subtraction of signals from two atomic voxels, was used to reject common-mode noise by two orders of magnitude or more.  Three methods of subtraction were explored – through signal post-processing, through light inversion, and through atom inversion.   In addition, a pair of magnetometers was used to distinguish the polarization of the magnetic field, which is advantageous in determining the source of the signal.

Sensitivities with small atomic volumes were improved by using a weak probe beam that passes through the atomic vapor numerous times. This method was found to be superior than using just a few passes of a high-power probe beam.  Sensitivities achieved rivaled those of earlier magnetometers with an order of magnitude larger volume.

Collaborators on the gradiometers, simultaneous/interleaved detection, and magnetometer operation with reduced atomic volumes include Prof. Romalis of Princeton and Dr. Kornack of Twinleaf LLC.

Through this grant, part of the upcoming generation of scientists was trained, with two graduate and five undergraduate students doing research in the Magnetic Resonance Laboratory at Mason.  In total they wrote eight published papers, with seven of those papers having the students as first authors. Of the five undergraduate students, one was a woman and two others were Hispanic.  Three of the five have gone on to graduate school in physics, and two others are in the application process. One of the graduate students received his PhD in physics and is now an NRC postdoctoral fellow at the Naval Research Laboratory.  The second student supported by this grant has advanced to candidacy for his PhD in physics. 

Outreach programs, supported by the program, focused on inspiring the next generation of middle-school and high-school students, pre-dominantly from under-represented populations, to consider STEM as an interesting career path.  Over a hundred students were impacted.  An after-school program at Glasgow Middle School, a school with close to 70% economically disadvantaged and 80% minority student enrollment, was conducted in collaboration with Angela DeHart, currently of STEM Impressionists.  In addition, workshops were created and ran for FOCUS, Females of Color and those Underrepresented in STEM Programs.  FOCUS is a week-long camp, under the directorship of Professor Kelly Knight of Mason, which exposes students to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines.

University students were brought up to be leaders in these outreach programs, both as an inspiration to the younger generation, but also to make the university students aware of STEM outreach and education.  Ten student leaders were engaged, with five of them being female, two of them being African American, and one of them being Hispanic.  Of these ten, two of them have gone on to be high school teachers, two of them work in the defense industry, one to graduate school in physics, and four of them are still in the physics program at Mason.
